title.narrative: Mission East - NGO call Afghanistan 2022-2023

description.narrative: Save lives, promote wellbeing and human rights and build resilience for the most vulnerable populations affected by the Afghanistan humanitarian crisis, in Afghanistan and Tajikistan.
FL §06.39.03.11 Other contributions to acute and prolonged crises

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Crises affected and vulnerable HHs in underserved communities receive long-term sustainable access to drinking water and adequate sanitation

• # of HHs provided with sustainable access to drinking water. • # o HHs in communities declared open defecation free (ODF)
Taget: Afg: 1000 HHs have improved access to sustainable potable water, through the construction/repair of 6 water systems. Afg: 1,000 HHs in 10 communities declared open defecation free (ODF)

target.value: Afg: 1000 HHs have improved access to sustainable potable water, through the construction/repair of 6 water systems. Afg: 1,000 HHs in 10 communities declared open defecation free (ODF)

title.narrative: Capacity of local population to defend their rights and lead their own development improved through better knowledge of rights-based approaches.

# of HHs provided with training on improved understanding of rights-based approaches
Target: Afg: 7,000 HHs supported through partners with training on rights-based approaches
Vulnerable individuals improve well-being, self-care and ability to protect their rights through trainings

# of individuals who have participated in training courses on basic health issues, healthy lifestyle and psychosocial topics
Target: Taj: 800 participants trained on rights and holistic well-being
Crises affected and vulnerable HHs in underserved communities receive immediate access to drinking water and adopt improved hygiene practices.

• # of HHs provided with hygiene/water kits and water purification chemicals • # of HH receiving information on sanitation and good hygiene practices
Target: Afg: 1000 HHs provided with hygiene items and information about personal and HH hygiene Taj: 480 HHs provided with hygiene items and information about personal and HH hygiene

target.value: Afg: 1,000 HHs provided with hygiene kits and water purification chemicals and information about personal and HH hygiene Taj: 240 HHs provided with hygiene items and information about personal and HH hygiene
Taj: 240 HHs provided with hygiene items and information about personal and HH hygiene

title.narrative: Crisis affected and vulnerable communities and HHs are supported to recover and improve food security and livelihoods, and with improved access to community infrastructure to reduce the use of negative coping strategies

• # of HHs supported with inputs and communal infrastructure to improve their food production and livelihoods
Total target;
Afg: 4370 farmers trained and provided with inputs to improve food security and / or livelihoods.
Afg: 1800 women trained and provided with inputs (Kitchen gardening, nutrition and food processing)
Afg: 350 of female headed HHs established passive solar greenhouses
Afg: 550 HH supported with rainwater harvesting systems and drip irrigation
Afg: 10 irrigation canals repaired / rehabilitated benefitting 1000 HH

target.value:
Afg: 1000 women trained and provided with inputs (kitchen gardening, nutrition and food processing)
Afg: 200 female headed HHs established passive solar greenhouses
Afg: 300 HHs supported with rainwater harvesting systems and drip irrigation
Afg: 5 irrigation canals repaired/rehabilitated benefitting 500 HH

Afg: 2,220 farmers trained and provided with inputs to improve food security and / or livelihoods.
Afg: 800 women trained and provided with inputs (Kitchen gardening, nutrition and food processing)
Afg: 150 of female headed HHs established passive solar greenhouses
Afg: 250 HHs supported with rainwater harvesting systems and drip irrigation
Afg: 5 irrigation canals repaired / rehabilitated benefitting 500 HH

title.narrative: Capacity of local civil society actors for principled, inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy, promotion of rights-based approaches, and representation of marginalized and vulnerable groups is strengthened and enhanced

# of local civil society actors supported with capacity strengthening.
Total target: Afg: 40 local NGOs trained on inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy and promotion of rights-based approaches Afg: 80 CSOs, agriculture cooperative, CDCs, community leaders, association, SHGs trained on inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy and promotion of rights-based approaches.

target.value:
Afg: 20 local NGOs trained on inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy and promotion of rights-based approaches
Afg: 40 CSOs, agriculture cooperatives, CDCs / Shuras, community leaders, associations and SHGs trained on inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy and promotion of rights-based approaches

Afg: 20 local NGOs trained on inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy and promotion of rights-based approaches
Afg: 40 CSOs, agriculture cooperative, CDCs, community leaders, association, SHGs trained on inclusive humanitarian and development action, advocacy and promotion of rights-based approaches.

title.narrative: Crisis affected and vulnerable HHs are assisted to meet their immediate humanitarian needs with cash interventions (Afg) and food /NFI distributions (Taj) in safe, timely and dignified ways

# of crisis affected and vulnerable HHs provided with timely access to food, NFI and/ or winterization support
Target: Afg: 11,000 crises affected and vulnerable HHs provided with cash for food, NFI and/ or winterization support Taj: 400 crises affected and vulnerable HHs provided with food items and non-food items

target.value: Afg: 6,500 crises affected and vulnerable HHs provided with cash for food, NFI and/ or winterization support Taj: 240 crises affected and vulnerable HHs provided food items and non-food items
Afg: 4,500 crises affected and vulnerable HHs provided with cash for food, NFI and/ or winterization support Taj: 240 HHs provided with food items and non-food items

title.narrative: Crisis affected and vulnerable HHs are supported with access to improved livelihood opportunities through provision of skills trainings and support to set up own business.

# of HH receiving access to new or improved livelihood opportunities through skills trainings and grants to set up business
Total target:
Taj: 160 participants provided with IGA / skills training
Taj: 40 HHs with improved means of income through setting up their own micro / small business

target.value:
Taj: 80 participants have been provided with Income generating activities (IGA ) / skills training
Taj: 20 HHs with improved means of income through setting up their own micro / small business

Taj: 80 participants provided with IGA / skills training
Taj: 20 HHs with improved means of income through setting up their own micro / small business

title.narrative: Vulnerable and crisis-affected communities are supported to become more resilient and recover better through restored HH food security and livelihood, and through safe, inclusive and equitable access to improved and sustainable productive infrastructure
• % of crisis-affected HHs reporting improved food security and livelihoods and reduced use of negative coping strategies

target.value: 5650 crises affected and vulnerable HH with improved food security and livelihood and access to essential community services and infrastructure. / 70%

title.narrative: Enhanced capacity of a range of local partners (Community level authorities, CBOs, CSOs and NGOs, both formal and informal) to serve as active ‘agents of change’ and to lead the process of relief and recovery together with crisis-affected communities

• % of project participants (local civil society actors and duty bearers) that report improved capacity for principled, inclusive and human-rights-based action, increased empowerment and better ability to defend their rights, and that of their constituents • % of people with improved knowledge of physical and mental health that results in improved hygiene, self-care, and well-being

target.value:
70% of project participants (local civil society actors and duty bearers) that report improved capacity for principled, inclusive and human-rights-based action, increased empowerment and better ability to defend their rights, and that of their constituents
70% of people with improved knowledge of physical and mental health that results in improved hygiene, self-care, and well-being

title.narrative: Vulnerable, crisis-affected communities are provided with life-saving assistance to meet critical needs in fragile and protracted contexts, thereby reducing the impact of negative coping strategies.
% of beneficiary households reporting that emergency assistance allowing them to meet essential humanitarian needs and received access to essential services
